Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Towards a Binary-Centric Framework for Cyber Forensics in Enterprise Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emerging attacks such as Advanced Persistent Threats pose significant threat to cyberspace. These attacks are often stealthy, low-and-slow, and disguised via deceptive campaigns. This research focuses on the forensics of cyber attacks targeting enterprise environments, with the goals of (1) understanding an attack's intent, strategy, steps, and targets, (2) collecting digital evidence for legal proceedings, (3) revealing hidden attack behaviors to prevent or minimize damage.

To achieve these goals, an integrated framework is being developed which covers three key aspects - temporal, spatial, and malware-behavioral forensics. All three aspects face the common challenge of analyzing binary executables. More specifically, temporal forensics requires finer-grain program logging for identifying attack provenance and ramifications. The solution is to partition a binary program's execution and data for high-accuracy causal analysis. Malware forensics involves revealing malware behaviors that are multi-stage, condition-guarded, and environment-specific. The solution is a new binary analysis approach that force-executes an unknown binary without input or environment setup and exposes the malware's behavior along the execution paths forced into. Temporal forensics requires understanding unknown file formats and in-memory data structure contents. The solution is to identify and reuse the file parsing/generation and data structure rendering logic in the corresponding binary programs.

This research will advance the state-of-the-art in cyber forensics, a critical need as our nation and society become increasingly dependent on cyberinfrastructures. It will help train next-generation cybersecurity experts by exposing students to real case investigations. Under-represented students are being involved in research activities and cyber forensics exercises.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this research involved improving the state-of-the-art in digital forensics, memory forensics, malware detection, and attribution of malicious computer activities. More simply, we were concerned with developing techniques to discover if and when malicious activities occurred, to try to understand the deeper intent behind the activities, what the resulting damage might be, and to collect actionable evidence for use in appropriate legal actions. This involved a number of efforts, including creating tools to automatically improve the security of mobile applications and to scan the internal storage of computers and mobile devices to uncover, correlate, and present evidence of malicious activity.

One of the tools we developed, called AspectDroid, automatically rewrites Android applications to make them safer and detects when applications perform suspicious activities. Another, called OpSeq, attempts to automatically discover malware hiding inside benign applications on mobile phones. Other techniques detect sophisticated malware on Mac OS X and expand the speed and scope of digital forensics efforts for Microsoft Windows. A new tool named Timeliner automatically creates timelines that illustrate the order in which mobile phone activities ocurrred. Another, called Retroscope, "looks back in time" to reveal historical activities on mobile phones. Techniques like these help to expose criminal activity, such as illegal exfiltration of sensitive data, texting while driving, and more.

Our research efforts contributed to the health, safety, and economic well-being of society, by trying to make computers and mobile devices safer to use and detecting when these devices are used in harmful ways. We were (and remain) deeply committed to expanding the ranks of and training the next generation of cybersecurity experts, through a number of outreach activities. These included informing K-12 students about the importance of cybersecurity, holding cybersecurity"bootcamps" that trained high school teachers so they can motivate their own students to study cybersecurity, engaging students in under-represented groups, by deeply involving university students in our research, and by integrating our research into classroom activities.
